content.content: About 75,000 patients die every year from healthcare-associated infections. That's enough people to fill 2 baseball stadiums! ![stadium](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/LA5l3cTOMMMYKKggq4ou0/0dc5cb5a4f4a21e7b382a98c24ee5c2d/stadium.jpeg) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/-FfMCv8FUXI ## Common healthcare-associated infections are:[^CommonInfections] - [Catheter-related Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000483.htm) - [Clostridium difficile Infections (C.diff)](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/clostridiumdifficileinfections.html) - [Surgical Site Infections](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/007645.htm) - [Hospital-acquired Pneumonia](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000146.htm) - [Central Line-associated Bloodstream Infections](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000474.htm) ### Any of the following can be caused by an infection:[^7][^10] - Extreme pain - Fever or chills - Redness, swelling, &/or pus - Confusion - Difficulty breathing - Very slow breathing - Dizziness - Unusual sweating - Rash or hives - Drop in blood pressure - High or low temperature - Changes in heart rate - Changes in breathing - Decrease in urine - The patient doesn’t look right Call the nurse if the patient “doesn’t seem right” or if the alarm goes off.[^7][^10] ![Patient-doctor [Converted] copy](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2HO5znpyiAwkISqyEmc22m/b57939de09454651df3be1d4e51c28c7/Patient-doctor__Converted__copy.svg) __Listen to your gut or intuition. __If no one is listening to you, speak with the Nurse Manager. ## Infection Prevention All healthcare providers and visitors must wash their hands. The average handwashing rate is 40% for healthcare providers in the hospital.[^58] __Never be afraid to ask your doctor or nurse to please wash their hands!__ Embedded content: https://youtu.be/tZnKlFtAUDw [Infection Prevention and You from APIC](http://www.apic.org/Resource_/TinyMceFileManager/consumers_professionals/APIC_IPandYou_YouAreImportant.pdf) ![handwashing](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3Qs1rsgcAwie0O404EcMW0/6e1c030c5df8f406f93b6163dd1a1eb4/handwashing.jpeg) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/D_vRYhEKAKA [Clean Hands Count from the CDC](http://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/pdfs/patient-factsheet-508.pdf "Clean Hands Count from the CDC") Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4HpcOpQaoQ 1\. Bring in hand sanitizer for the patient, healthcare providers, and visitors to use. Ask your doctor or nurse to wash their hands __with__ you. ![hand sanitizer provider](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2q5V25fwig4Ak4SGgiEio/4c336dc17006aa5df8d94657aac89786/hand_sanitizer_provider.jpeg) 2\. Use disinfectant wipes on all surfaces that you or the patient will come in contact with. Ask the nurse for these.[^61] ![sanitizing wipe](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/smiMs9183uw0MI8MokmSy/ee88d5019c968395e32e34a21128feed/sanitizing_wipe.jpeg) 3\. Put up a sign telling staff to wash their hands on your door and above your bed.[^61] 4\. Make sure doctors and nurses wipe the round end of the stethoscope with an alcohol wipe.[^61] Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8AKTACyiB0 5\. Gloves need to be worn when there is contact with blood or other body fluids, mouth, nose, lungs, urinary and digestive tracts, open skin areas, or items that are soiled with blood or other body fluids. __Healthcare workers need to wash their hands both before and after using gloves. Wearing gloves is never a substitute for hand washing![^7] Gloves can have microscopic tears and holes.__ ![nitrile gloves](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4rg2Fta5E4aeiaigMMIwEK/394f7d31c513fcc1ce76efacff603cc7/nitrile_gloves.jpeg) 6\. Healthcare providers and visitors need to follow Isolation Precautions of wearing gowns, gloves and sometimes masks if the patient's door has an Isolation Precaution sign on it. [Isolation Precaution Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000446.htm) ![isolation stuff](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6VTF4KABnayciesYuYEGMY/5b5f6c8e53d2c9261b6e6c7df9876595/isolation_stuff.svg) 7\. The patient must wash their hands before eating every meal and before going to sleep.[^7] 8\. Cellphones are dirty[^63][^64] - Wipe your cell phone with an alcohol wipe. - Do not take a cell phone into the bathroom. - Do not place the cell phone on the floor, especially the bathroom floor. 9\. Cover your mouth when you cough or sneeze. Use your elbow or arm instead of your hands. 10\. When a nurse is giving IV medications, make sure the nurse cleans the IV port for 15 seconds before and after with an alcohol wipe.[^65] Don’t touch __where your IV lines meet your skin__.[^66] ![iv arm](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6UwMhxhQjeYysEGk8GgiC8/b22dc225e9d6b286d7ac3995eb4faed9/iv_arm.jpeg) 11\. Tell your nurse and doctor if there is pain, swelling, redness, itching or wetness at an IV line or incision. Embedded content: https://youtu.be/67vDXQMxUz4 12\. Ask if you or the patient can have their own blood pressure cuff to be used only by them.[^7] ![stethoscope bpc](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3rEpJHB2R2g8uu44yAe8Qc/490f0da52aec12da4fa003b064c00cab/stethoscope_bpc.jpeg) 13\. Remove your slippers worn over socks __before getting back into your bed. This prevents germs from the floor coming into your bed.__[^7] 14\. All visitors need to:[^7] - Wash their hands before entering and leaving the room - Do not visit if they feel ill - Avoid using the patient’s bathroom [Prevention of Infections from Visitors by the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000448.htm) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/hNo808Nx0bs ## Prevention of Catheter-related Urinary Tract Infection (UTIs) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/CXJleBIGQQ8 1\. Ask when is the soonest a urinary catheter can be removed.[^7] 2\. Urinary catheters should be removed within 2 days of being inserted. If a urinary catheter needs to be inserted, it needs to be done under sterile conditions.[^7] [Catheter-related Urinary Tract Infection Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000483.htm) [Antibiotics for People with Catheters from Choosing Wisely by the American Board of Internal Medicine (ABIM) ](http://www.choosingwisely.org/patient-resources/antibiotics-for-people-with-catheters/) [Catheter-related Urinary Tract Infection information from the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America ](http://www.shea-online.org/images/patients/ENGLISH_SHEA_Brochure_on_healthcare_associated_infections.pdf) ## Prevention of Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) Infection Embedded content: https://youtu.be/E3AspGb-QA4 Healthcare providers and visitors must wash their hands with soap and water and wear gloves, gowns, and/or masks (Isolation Precautions) when caring for patients who have a C. difficile infection. __Soap and water are more effective at hand cleaning than hand sanitizer with a C. difficile infection.__[^71] [Clostridium difficile Infection Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/clostridiumdifficileinfections.html) ![nurse mask](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3E5uj13yXeSgEiKMaEUkC8/0bb3e02ebcbf637e4a63f2ac2d2428fe/nurse_mask.jpeg) [Clostridium difficile information from the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America ](http://www.shea-online.org/images/patients/ENGLISH_SHEA_Brochure_on_healthcare_associated_infections.pdf) [Isolation Precaution Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000446.htm) ## Prevention of Surgical Site Infection Embedded content: https://youtu.be/gaBJUR-8QvE __Before Surgery:__ To prevent surgical site infections the CDC infection prevention guidelines are: - Doctors and nurses __need to__ clean their hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand rub before and after caring for each patient. - In most cases, you should get antibiotics within 60 minutes before surgery starts and the antibiotics should be stopped within 24 hours after surgery. - Clean the patient's skin at the site of surgery with a special soap that kills germs before surgery. __After surgery:__ - If you do not see your providers clean their hands, please ask them to do so. - Family and friends who visit you should not touch the surgical wound or dressings. - Family and friends should clean their hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand rub before and after visiting you. If you do not see them clean their hands, ask them to clean their hands. - Make sure you understand how to care for your wound before you leave the hospital. - Always clean your hands before and after caring for your wound. - Make sure you know who to contact if you have questions or problems after you get home. - If you have any symptoms of an infection, such as redness and pain at the surgery site, drainage, or fever in the hospital, call your RN.[^73] [Surgical Site Infection information from the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America ](http://www.shea-online.org/images/patients/ENGLISH_SHEA_Brochure_on_healthcare_associated_infections.pdf) [Surgical Site Infection Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/007645.htm) ## Prevention of Hospital-acquired Pneumonia Embedded content: https://youtu.be/4rFjAmaDXlg If the patient is on a ventilator[^75][^76]: - Ask for a daily check of the patient's ability to breathe without the ventilator's help. - Help make sure the patient's back and head are always at least at a 30 degree angle. - Tell the nurse if the patient slides down in the bed. - Ask about reducing the amount of sedation medication or a "sedation vacation". - Ask about walking the patient. - Watch for bed sores on the patient's lower back and buttocks. - Encourage deep breathing with the incentive spirometer.  - __The patient should do at least 10 deep breaths every hour using the incentive spirometer while in bed.__[^78] [Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP) Fact Sheet from SHEA ](http://www.shea-online.org/images/patients/ENGLISH_SHEA_Brochure_on_healthcare_associated_infections.pdf) [Hospital-acquired Pneumonia Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000146.htm) ![incentive spirometer](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4FE0Ueh8xi8C8aOoM8euUC/28cc668d6148ca40013aeff37a2a740a/incentive_spirometer.jpeg) [Incentive Spirometer Use Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000451.htm) ## Prevention of Central Catheter Intravenous Line Infection Embedded content: https://youtu.be/sFROH5rvWOY __Don’t touch where your IV lines are.__ ![central line](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/1VNQ5iOqsQA8MKWaqOASQG/af200796edf86741528626b907422330/central_line.jpeg) When a central catheter IV line is inserted, make sure there is: - Careful hand washing - Barrier precautions used during line insertion (including hair covers, masks, sterile gloves, sterile gown, eye protection) - Cleaning the skin with chlorhexidine gluconate skin prep - Avoid using the femoral vein (upper leg near the groin) - Daily review of the need for the central catheter IV and prompt removal of unnecessary IVs.[^80][^81] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/-DNuFp6KDVM [Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infection Fact Sheet from the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America ](http://www.shea-online.org/images/patients/ENGLISH_SHEA_Brochure_on_healthcare_associated_infections.pdf) [Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infection Information from the CDC ](https://www.cdc.gov/HAI/bsi/CLABSI-resources.html) [Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infection Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000474.htm) [Central Venous Catheter Information from the American Thoracic Society ](https://www.thoracic.org/patients/patient-resources/resources/central-venous-catheter.pdf) [^CommonInfections]: Office of Disease Prevention & Health Promotion (ODPHP).
